question: What remains in the same location in the sky of the Northern Hemisphere each night? (A) the Sun (B) the Little Dipper (C) the North Star (D) the Moon

Why do we see different stars in the sky at different times of the year? (A) The stars are revolving around the Sun. (B) The Moon is revolving around Earth. (C) Earth is revolving around the Sun. (D) The stars are revolving around Earth.

Which of the following best explains why the Sun appears to move across the sky every day? (A) The Sun rotates on its axis. (B) Earth rotates on its axis. (C) The Sun orbits around Earth. (D) Earth orbits around the Sun.

Why are different stars seen during different seasons? (A) Some stars shine brighter during different seasons. (B) The Sun shines on different stars during different seasons. (C) Earth changes position in its orbit during different seasons. (D) The Moon changes position in its orbit during different seasons.

Stars are organized into patterns called constellations. One constellation is named Leo. Which statement best explains why Leo appears in different areas of the sky throughout the year? (A) Earth revolves around the sun. (B) The sun revolves around Earth. (C) The constellations revolve around Earth. (D) Earth revolves around the constellations.

How does the appearance of a constellation change during the night? (A) Its shape appears to become longer. (B) Its position appears to shift relative to the horizon. (C) Its brightest stars begin to appear orange. (D) Its distance to the North Star decreases.
Which event occurs once per day? (A) The Moon rises. (B) The new Moon occurs. (C) The Moon cycles through its phases. (D) The Moon passes in front of the Sun.
